instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-3536: What is 820-3536? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.Q7180: What is Q7180? Inrush limiter transistor that must be told by the ISL6259 that it is safe to allow charger voltage to pass through to the computer. This needs CHGR_AGATE and CHGR_SGATE to be pulled down in order for it to close and allow voltage through to the system, current sensing failures as well as ISL6259 failures can cause this to happen. .
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid spill
threads.message: fully functional except wasn't seeing screen, I cleaned and now just no backlight. Anyone have the schematic or board view? I tried using <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> as everyone else recommends but the bottom where the damage was (<CHIP>U8330</CHIP>) side is different

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid spill
threads.message: do you have 0v, 12v, or 50v on pin 1 of the lcd connector?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid spill
threads.message: Yes just checked and getting 50v and interestingly enough when i put the probe there the screen intermittently illuminates.  After giving it a few minutes it's almost steady now, but the screen is displaying garbage vertical colored lines.  For the hell of it I put on another LCD and LVDS and that seems to be fine, so I guess the guy fried his LCD with the backlight over voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid spill
threads.message:
No Title

I haven't tried taken the shielding off the lcd pcb yet but was wondering if anyone else had and what the prospects for repair that would be (in such a situation like this, because the screen isn't cracked)

and i should have some cracked screens i could salvage the pcbs from

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid spill
threads.message: 50v means the boost circuit is working but it doesn't see a load. either the lcd cable is bad, the connector on the lcd is bad, or the backlight is bad. it is possible inside the lcd connector on the board is bad as well, but that would be the last place I look

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid spill
threads.message: thanks louis but like i said, i already confirmed the LCD is fried.  new question is how hard is it to repair lcd pcb and getting those heat shields off?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid spill
threads.message: Waste if time to try and fix it. Get an assembly and be done with it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid spill
threads.message:
This is what i get opening these tabs and trying to post around work. i get beat to making posts!

you are not fixing an lcd PCB, just replace. You can replace the entire assembly, or just the LCD, but fixing the LCD is a waste. i buy the cell for $85 and my receptionist can replace it in a half hour.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid spill
threads.message:
Apparently there is more wrong with this than previously thought.
  [FONT=Helvetica]I thought everything was fine after putting on a new screen.[/FONT]
  [FONT=Helvetica]However that was apparently only running off battery, but not from charger.  With a cord the screen shows the charging battery but never actually does.[/FONT]
  [FONT=Courier][SIZE=7px] [/SIZE][/FONT]
  [FONT=Courier]<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>[FONT=Times] and[/FONT] <SIGNAL>HGR_AGATE_DIV</SIGNAL> both coming in at around 19v with an 85w (assuming) preventing <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> from opening.  <CAPACITOR>C7185</CAPACITOR> and <RESISTOR>R7185</RESISTOR> have both been replaced to no avail.  Also tried a new ISL, still doing the same.[/FONT]
  [FONT=Times]Any ideas?[/FONT]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid spill
threads.message: Sense resistors around <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>, has been discussed many times. Use search function.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid spill
threads.message: Thanks!  After testing all of them, found 2 were bad.  Replaced those and still having the same issue though, any further suggestions?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid spill
threads.message: which ones where bad???  What is the resistance between pins 17 and 18 from <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid spill
threads.message: Check resistance between pins 17/18 of <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> and pins 27/28 and report back.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid spill
threads.message: Was around 4ohm between 17/18 and 20 or so between 27/28.  Replaced <CAPACITOR>C7121</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7122</CAPACITOR> and now resistance is 0, but still having the same issue.
